item.title: We Rewrote the Ghostty GTK Application
item.description: We just completed rewriting the Ghostty GTK application fully embracing the GObject type system from Zig and also verifying with Valgrind every step of the way. The result is a more feature rich, stable, and maintainable Ghostty on Linux and BSD.

item.title: Typing to Think, Speaking to Prompt
item.description: My earlier post about the rise of voice as a UI had me pondering what exactly is it that makes voice input ideal in some circumstances and entirely undesired in others. Spoken language is faster per word and, in a naive economic sense, ‚Äúbetter‚Äù1. And yet, there are times where I have no interest in ‚Äúgoing fast‚Äù. Why? This topic makes me think of Andy Clark‚Äôs Supersizing the Mind, which opens with a famous Feynman quote about insisting that his ‚Äúdaily notes‚Äù were not simply a record of his activities but his actual thinking:

GPT-5 Router - Inevitable Future of Chat Interfaces

item.title: Is MCP just a WSDL Reboot for LLMs?
item.description: If the Model Context Protocol gives you 2005 vibes, you‚Äôre not imagining it. MCP feels like the good part of the old web-services dream brought forward for AI agents: describe what you can do, let a generic client discover it, and integrate without bespoke glue. That was the pitch behind WSDL in the Web 2.0 era‚ÄîWeb Services Description Language‚Äîan XML contract where a service declared its operations, messages, and types so tools could generate clients automatically. If you‚Äôve never seen it, the original specs still read like a time capsule: WSDL 1.1 and WSDL 2.0.

item.description: From the Zed Blog: Steve Yegge and Nathan Sobo debate whether IDEs are obsolete in the AI era. Their opposing perspectives reveal surprising common ground.

item.title: The fixed length bottleneck and the feed forward network
item.description: The feed-forward network in an LLM processes context vectors one at a time. This feels like it would cause similar issues to the old fixed-length bottleneck, even though it almost certainly does not.

item.title: Our relationship to technology is broken
item.description:
The other day I texted an old friend. His name had come up in conversation, and I wanted him to know I was thinking of him.¬†
His reply came swiftly:
‚ÄúWhen are you gonna get an iPhone? ü§£‚Äù
My friend is a gifted communicator. Rather than engage in a stilted back

item.title: I wanted to take more pictures, so I vibecoded a portfolio
item.description: Warning: English is not my native language and I refused to ask an LLM to write this for me, so at least you got a somewhat human blogpost in exchange for some bad english :P I‚Äôve had an interest in photography for a long time, I remember being fascinated by it in highschool and since then I still enjoy looking at pictures, reading about photography (suffering from GAS) and most of all, taking pictures.

item.title: Why I Quit Competitive Programming
item.description: TL;DR # I tried competitive programming for a whole year and it didn‚Äôt work out well for me, I didn‚Äôt enjoy it and didn‚Äôt achieve anything remarkable as well. So it‚Äôs better to take the L and move on and try other things I wanted to try, but I couldn‚Äôt because of competitive programming. For the rest of the article I‚Äôm going to talk about the sunk cost fallacy.

item.title: I am a Windows User
item.description: I'm pretty good at bootstrapping a new PC. Taking it from the box, installing all my software, changing all my preferred settings takes me about three hours. I have nobody who does it for me, but I also have nobody who messes up my setup with corporate policies. My PC does not behave like your...

item.title: Lasso Transactions as an alternative to Copyright
item.description: Often, people who oppose copyright give weak excuses as for how a market would sustain artists creating work, without the government creating an artificial monopoly on said work. In a recent conversation with one of my friends who also oppose many aspects of the current copyright system, we brainstormed alternatives. I opposed the traditional donation model as it‚Äôs highly subject to free-rider problem, and demanded that a new model be created1, if we should reasonably expect to convince people to oppose copyright.
